ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Insights into the intersection between the medical field and the American family, with issues of gender, race and class also discussed. This course greatly improved my critical thinking and ability to read into historical texts

I learned about women and the influence of the institution of marriage in the history of medicine. We learned about elements of history that I hadn't covered in other classes, and I learned a very intersectional history of medicine. I also further developed critical thinking skills when in conversation with my peers.
Learned to think critically about the intersections of medicine and gender, sexuality, ability, and class
Interesting reading and critical analysis of medical practitioners from a new lens

I learned so much about the history of the intersection between gender, sexuality, and medicine. This was one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Yale. I also think that I gained a much better sense of how to write a historical research paper and more effectively find and use primary sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed reading stories from different surgeons and perspectives, however I felt like it was a bit disjointed at times
I loved this course, the format was great and I think we were really encouraged to participate and have insightful discussions

The main strength of this class was the structure of the assignments. I really liked how every assignment built up to the final essay. It made me feel prepared and ready to write my 15-page final paper (which sometimes can be daunting). I felt very supported throughout the entire semester!
Very well organized! Loved the readings each week and how class discussion was structured. LOVED the interactive activities and times when we got to "play" as different historical characters.

It was super interesting and the weekly discussions were thoughtful and well structured. Some of the assignments through the semester felt a little more like busy work, and it wouldve been nice to have assignments that related to content in the course in addition to preparatory assignments for the final paper. That said, it was well organized and manageable.

I loved this course and the readings we were assigned. I thought our discussions were fascinating as well. However, because we often had so much reading that covered a large period of time, I would have loved some lectures in class that helped to place everything in a timeline and provide a broader historical context to which we could attach all the readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes but it was different than I anticipated it to be focus wise
Yes! Anyone interested in the history of medicine and gender studies should definitely take this class

I definitely would recommend this course to another student because the topics are very interesting and unique, and the course assignment structure was great. I also love Professor O'Donnell! She made the content even more interesting than it already was.

Highly recommend. Prof. O'Donnell is great, gives you lots of feedback, is very responsive. Course material is super interesting and covers lots of different topics, and she is wonderful at keeping class discussions and activities very engaging! The assignments are great and slowly help you write your research paper over the course of the semester so you're not overwhelmed at the last minute and have lots of time to think and get feedback. It was a super fulfilling project to work on!

Yes, if youre interested in the darker side of medicine and the intersection of medicine and marital autonomy it is a must take! For a premed its a great opportunity to think critically about the field.
Absolutely! Professor O'Donnell is wonderful and so knowledgeable about this topic, and I learned so much that will inform my work as a history major and understanding of my reproductive health.
